title: Withdrawing cash prior to filing bankruptcy?
question: Uh oh, I hope I didn't do something "illegal" by withdrawing money that I will need to pay for the car maintenance, rent and childcare. What should I do if someone asks me about this money? It's about $7000.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Statement of financial affairs,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud
answers:
Where is the money? If you have it in your hands and it was disclosed, then all you did was convert the asset from liquid (bank account) to liquid (cash). No harm was done. If you did not list it, or you failed to disclose payments made to creditors of more than $600 within the 90 days before filing. If you spent it on living expenses before you filed, like child care, then it would not need to be listed anywhere.

Two cautions, disclose everything and be upfront about everything or face possible sanctions. Second, some trustees request the most recent bank statement and will see the withdrawal. Everything can be found out, just be prepared to explain it and have proof to back it up.

[This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

If you have filed the bankruptcy already and did not list the cash as am asset and then claim an appropriate exemption in the cash, then you will need to amend your schedules immediately. If you have not yet filed be sure that they will be listed.

Failures to accurately list your property can result in your case being dismissed or worse your discharge denied. In some cases they can be prosecuted for perjury and bankruptcy fraud, federal felonies.

Withdrawing money and converting it to cash is not in itself illegal. The remaining cash (if any) needs to be disclosed on your petition as an asset. Recent payments to creditors need to be disclosed on your Statement of Financial Affairs (see Question 3). If a trustee or creditor asks you about the money and what you did with it, tell the truth. Always a good idea to have receipts to verify your statements. You want your petition, testimony and receipts to be consistent. If you do not have an attorney, it's a good idea to hire one. Good luck.
